IMAGING
========
___ NCHCT
IMPRESSION: No acute intracranial abnormality, specifically, no 
evidence of large
territorial infarction, hemorrhage, or brain abscess.

___ TTE
LVEF 55-60% IMPRESSION: Tricuspid valve mass (see above) with at 
least moderate to severe tricuspid regurgitation, mild global 
right ventricular hypokinesis, volume overload on the left 
ventricle. No vegetation seen on the ___ nor mitral 
valve.
Compared with the prior TTE ___ , tricuspid regurgitation 
is increased. The right ventricle is hypokinetic. There is 
volume overload on the left ventricle. The tricuspid valve mass 
is similar. Aortic valve gradients slightly higher but leaflets 
move normally. Permanent RV lead now present.

___ ___
  
No evidence of deep venous thrombosis in the right lower 
extremity veins. 

___ Foot Xray:
There is some irregularity and spurring along the lateral base 
of the first 
proximal phalanx of the great toe.  This may represent 
degenerative changes or 
sequela of old injury.  No discrete fracture line is seen; 
however, please 
correlate with pain at this location. 
  
There is normal osseous mineralization.  There is some spurring 
about the 
posterior calcaneus near the Achilles tendon attachment.  There 
are no 
erosions. 

___: Renal U/S
1. Echogenic appearance of the kidneys likely reflects chronic 
medical renal 
disease. 
2. Trabeculated bladder may reflect chronic outlet obstruction. 

___ MRI cervical, thoracic, and lumbar spine:
 
1. Severe spinal canal narrowing with crowding and possibly 
compression of the cauda equina at L2-3, mildly progressed since 
___, largely in part due to an inferiorly extruded 8 
mm L2-3 disc fragment.  Correlate clinically with any clinical 
signs of cauda equina syndrome. 
2. No evidence of discitis-osteomyelitis in the cervical, 
thoracic, or lumbar spine. 
3. Multifocal short-segment T2/STIR hyperintense cord signal 
abnormalities in the cervical spine are similar appearance to 
prior study from ___ however poorly visualized due to 
technical limitations of the study as above; within these 
confines, these appear unchanged and late to chronic 
myelomalacia. 
4. Multilevel cervical spine degenerative changes.  Spinal canal 
narrowing is worst (moderate to severe) at C6-7. 
5. Expected cervical spine postoperative changes.  Expected 
lumbar spine 
postoperative changes.  Mild residual edema, likely 
postoperative, and/or 
muscle strain in the lower lumbar spine erector spinae.  No 
focal fluid 
collection. 
6. Multilevel high-grade degenerative lumbar spine neural 
foraminal narrowing. 
7. No acute findings in the thoracic spine. Mild thoracic spine 
degenerative 
change. 
8. Possible small left layering pleural effusion, poorly 
visualized.  Other 
incidental findings, as above. 
  
RECOMMENDATION(S):  Correlation with any symptoms or physical 
examination 
signs of cauda equina syndrome is recommended, as above. 

TEE ___:
There is no spontaneous echo contrast or thrombus in the body of 
the left atrium/left atrial appendage. The
left atrial appendage ejection velocity is normal. No 
spontaneous echo contrast or thrombus is seen in the body of the 
right atrium/right atrial appendage. No thrombus/vegetation is 
seen on the catheter/wire. The interatrial septum is dynamic, 
but not frankly aneurysmal. There is no evidence for an atrial 
septal defect by 2D/color Doppler. Overall left ventricular 
systolic function is normal. There are no aortic arch atheroma 
with simple atheroma in the descending aorta to 45 cm from the 
incisors. A ___ 3 aortic valve bioprosthesis is present. The 
prosthesis is well seated with normal leaflet motion. No masses 
or vegetations are seen on the aortic valve. No abscess is seen. 
There is no aortic regurgitation. The mitral valve leaflets are 
mildly thickened with no mitral valve prolapse. No masses or 
vegetations are seen on the mitral valve. No abscess is seen. 
There is moderate [2+] mitral regurgitation. The tricuspid valve 
leaflets appear structurally normal. A LARGE (1.1 cm long) 
mobile echodensity is seen on the right atrial side of the 
tricuspid valve most c/w a VEGETATION. No abscess is seen. There 
is moderate to severe [3+] tricuspid regurgitation. Due to 
acoustic shadowing, the severity of tricuspid regurgitation may 
be UNDERestimated. There is mild pulmonary artery systolic 
hypertension. There is no pericardial effusion.

IMPRESSION: There is a large 1.1 cm mobile echodensity on the 
right atrial side of the tricuspid valve most consistent with a 
vegetation. No abscess seen.Moderate to severe tricuspid 
regurgitation. Well-seated ___ 3 ___ with normal leaflet 
motion and no masses or vegetation
or regurgitation. Moderate mitral regurgitation.

CT Chest ___:
1. Small Left pleural effusion and trace of right pleural 
effusion. 
2. Associated linear consolidations are likely secondary to 
atelectasis.  
Superimposed infection is possible but thought to be less 
likely. 
3. Moderate cardiomegaly. 
4. Uncomplicated cholelithiasis.

Brief Hospital Course:
*** We anticipate this patient will require <30 days at rehab 
****

SUMMARY
========
___ year old male with history of bicuspid aortic valve (s/p 
bioprosthetic AVR initially in ___ with a redo AVR as well as 
aortic replacement in ___, s/p ___ ___, second-degree AV 
block s/p PPM in ___ and subsequent generator change in ___, isolated atrial fibrillation (detected on pacemaker 
___, on eliquis), RCC (s/p R partial nephrectomy in ___, 
c/b CKD), HFpEF, bipolar, and depression s/p ECT who was 
transferred from ___ with altered mental status and 
fever. Repeat blood cultures have all been negative for 
recurrent bacteremia given recent admission for strep 
bacteremia. TEE showed a stable TV mass consistent with 
pacemaker lead extraction. MRI of the whole spine was negative 
for osteomyelitis. Given no evidence of recurrent infection, all 
antibiotics were stopped. Fevers did not return and the patient 
was discharged to rehab given this was a likely viral infection. 


ACUTE ISSUES:
=============
#Fever
#H/o strep bacteremia 
The patient had a recent admission from ___ for 
pacemaker extraction in the setting of strep sanguinis 
bacteremia. The pacemaker was removed with no complication and 
last positive culture was on ___. Given recent dental 
procedure, dentistry evaluated the patient, but did not think 
this was the cause of his bacteremia. TEE at the time showed a 
TV mass on ___, but this is likely due to pacemaker extraction. 
PPM was reimplanted on ___ and discharged on IV ceftriaxone 
2g daily. The patient represented with AMS concerning for 
recurrent bacteremia, but blood cultures were all negative. ID 
was consulted and recommend repeat TEE which showed stable TV 
mass consistent with PPM extraction per EP. MRI spine showed no 
evidence of osteomyelitis. Discussion was had regarding need for 
cardiac CT to evaluate for abscess but this was deferred given 
contrast load. PET-CT was considered to evaluate for ___ 
infection but given defervescence of fevers this was deferred. 
CRP remained elevated, but given clinical improvement no 
additional imaging was done.  Vancomycin and ceftriaxone were 
discontinued early on ___ prior to full 6 week course planned 
for presumed endocarditis which was ___ and patient's fevers 
did not recur (per infectious disease). The leading thought 
remains fevers were from a viral illness. 

___ on CKD
His Cr was stably elevated during last hospitalization 
(2.5-3.1), which may represent new baseline, and was 3.2 on 
admission. He was given fluid resuscitation early in the 
admission, developed crackles, elevated right-sided pressures 
noted on TTE, therefore a component of cardiorenal was 
considered. He was diuresed and developed a worsening ___ 
consistent with ATN. His diuretic was held and ATN improved. Cr 
stabilized at 2.5 and Torsemide was restarted. 

#Chronic HFpEF
EF 65%. His discharge weight from ___ was 92.6 kg (204.14 lb). 
Admission weight 93.5 kg (206.13 lb). He received fluids early 
in the admission for presumed sepsis, became overloaded and was 
hemodynamically stable so was diuresed. Metoprolol was decreased 
given borderline blood pressure. Cr on discharge 2.5. Weight on 
discharge 100.8kg and 222.22lbs  but this was a bed weight. 

#Macrocytic anemia:
#Thrombocytopenia: Hgb 8.6 at last discharge, 8.3 on admission. 
Likely anemia of inflammation iso infection vs chronic back pain 
and CKD. Differential for macrocytic anemia may also include MDS 
given some degree of thrombocytopenia and increased MCV. Less 
likely hemolysis with normal AST and inappropriately low retics. 
This was stable on discharge. 

#Altered mental status
#Toxic metabolic encephalopathy
Presented with new onset inattention, disorientation. Likely due 
to systemic infection, renal failure, increased accumulation of 
gabapentin and Ativan with reduced renal function, perhaps 
cephalosporin neurotoxicity (though ceftriaxone not a big 
offender). NCHCT neg, non focal neuro exam. Mental status 
improved throughout hospital course.

#Acute on chronic "back" pain in R posterior hip
#History of spinal stenosis s/p surgery
He reported pain in his right lower back, which appeared to be 
the pelvis with pain radiating down his right leg and subjective 
numbness of the right foot that began a few days after having a 
fall on ___ hitting his hip and acutely worsened in the past 
week after being hospitalized and in bed. Given fever, and c/f 
bacteremia, osteo was considered. MRI showed evidence of cord 
compression, but in the absence of new neurologic findings, the 
patient will follow up with neurosurgery as an option for 
further options (this was discussed with patient's 
neurosurgeon). Physical therapy recommended rehab. 

#Rash:
Patient developed an erythematous rash on his back with 
sloughing of his skin concerning for contact dermatitis from the 
sheets and moisture from sweat. This had improvement with 
antifungal powder and keeping the area open to air. 

CHRONIC ISSUES:  
================
#Atrial fibrillation: 
He is AV paced, was continued on apixaban 5 BID, and metoprolol.

# Hx of AV block s/p PPM
On last admission, PPM explanted on ___ and replaced on ___. 
Device interrogated post re-implantation and DDD mode with 100% 
pacing.

# ?History of COPD
This diagnosis is questionable as patient and wife do not 
remember a diagnosis of COPD, no PFTs in our system, never 
tobacco use, no bronchitis type symptoms, though his wife 
reports he is on ___ different inhalers at home. Provided 
flovent and albuterol inhaler. This diagnosis should be 
clarified with his primary care physician.

# History of obstructive sleep apnea: Refused CPAP in the past.
- Discuss benefits of CPAP with patient

# Psychiatric history
# Bipolar disorder, depression
- Continued divalproex and lamotrigine

# Tremor: Could be secondary to intention tremor or a medication 
induced tremor (from Depakote) or possibly essential tremor. 
Gabapentin was initially held in the setting of renal failure. 
Tremor improved when this was restarted.
 
# BPH
- Continued tamsulosin qhs

# Anxiety:
Held home ativan 1mg TID PRN.

# Health maintenance, hyperlipidemia
Continued aspirin daily, rosuvastatin (dosed M/Th)

TRANSITIONAL ISSUES
=================
DISCHARGE Cr 2.5
DISCHARGE weight 100.8kg and 222.22lbs but this was a BED weight 

DISCHARGE HGB; 8.2
DISCHARGE AST/ALT: 48 and 57

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___,  

It was a privilege caring for you at ___ 
___.  

WHY WAS I IN THE HOSPITAL?  
- You were transferred from ___ due to  
confusion, fevers, and concern you may have a bloodstream 
infection with possible infection in your pacemaker or aortic 
valve replacement. 

WHAT HAPPENED TO ME IN THE HOSPITAL?  
- We did a full evaluation for infection including blood 
cultures, MRI of the spine, CT scan of the chest and 
transesophageal echocardiogram. These were all negative for 
infection. 
- The infectious disease team, electrophysiology specialists and 
cardiologists worked with us and did not identify a cause for 
your fevers. The most likely cause of the fevers were from a 
virus. 
- You kidneys suffered some injury so the nephrology team was 
consulted and recommended holding your Torsemide. Your kidneys 
eventually recovered back to its baseline and your Torsemide was 
restarted. 
- Your antibiotics were held and no additional fevers developed 
and then discontinued. 
- You had fluid removed with diuretics. 
- Your blood pressure medications were adjusted given lower 
blood pressures. 

WHAT SHOULD I DO AFTER I LEAVE THE HOSPITAL?  
- Please continue to check for fevers at rehab.
- Monitor your weights and call your doctor if your week 
increases >3lbs in a day or >5lbs in a week. 
- Continue to take all your medicines and keep your 
appointments.  

We wish you the best.

Sincerely,  
Your ___ Team  

 
Followup Instructions:

qafib.question: Does the note describe the patient as having permanent, paroxysmal, or persistent afib?

qprior_stroke.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever having a stroke or transient ischemic attack?

qarterial_hypertension.question: Does the note describe the patient as having arterial hypertension on treatment (high bp e.g. >140, or HTN)?

qt2d.question: Does the note describe the patient as having Diabetes mellitus (DM1, DM2, T2D, T1DM, T2DM)?

qheart_failure.question: Does the note describe the patient as having heart failure?

qsurgical_valvular_disease.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever having valvular disease requiring surgery (stenosis)?

qafib_ablation.question: Does the note describe the patient as having a planned or past ablation procedure for afib?

qbleeding.question: Does the note describe the patient as having a serious bleeding in the past 6 months?

qpeptic_ulcer_disease.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever having peptic ulcer disease?

qrecent_stroke.question: Does the note describe the patient as having a stroke during this admission or within the last month? (Answer yes for any recent stroke if the date is unclear)

qhemorrhagic.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever having any hemorrhagic tendencies or blood dyscrasias?

qbipolar.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever being diagnosed with bipolar disorder?

qschizophrenia.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever being diagnosed with schizophrenia or any schizoaffective disorders?

qmdd.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever being diagnosed with depression or major depressive disorder (MDD)?

qmed_decisions.question: Does the note describe the patient as being unable to make medical decisions? (Answer no unless there is evidence the patient cannot make their own medical decisions).

qchads2.question: What is the highest CHADS2 score mentioned? Answer "NA" if no CHADS2 score is in the note.

qblood_glucose.question: What is the highest blood glucose lab mentioned? Answer "NA" if no blood glucose score is in the note.

qlvef.question: What is the lowest left ventricular ejection (LVEF, ef, ejection fraction) fraction mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no LVEF is in the note, Answer 55 if the lowest value is 55% or greater.

qPLT.question: What is the lowest platelet count (PLT) mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no platelet count is available in the note.

qHGB.question: What is the lowest hemoglobin (HGB) mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no HGB value is available in the note.

qCREAT.question: What is the higest serum creatinine (Creat) mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no creatinine value is available in the note.

qAST.question: What is the higest aspartate aminotransferase level (AST) mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no AST value is available in the note.

qBILI.question: What is the higest total bilirubin (TotBili, Bili) mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no bilirubin value is available in the note.
